CERTIFICATION
   We, Lynn Webb, Mayor, and Emma Nelson, Clerk of Council, of Kenton, Ohio,
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 731.23 and 731.42, hereby certify that the general and
permanent legislation of the City of Kenton, Ohio, as revised, arranged,
compiled, numbered, codified and printed herewith in component codes, is
correctly set forth and constitutes the Codified Ordinance of the City of
Kenton, Ohio, 1973, complete to April 22, 2024.
   /s/   Lynn Webb
      Mayor
   /s/   Emma Boutwell
      Clerk of Council

COMPARATIVE SECTION TABLE
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Source material for the 1973 Codified Ordinances of Kenton
was either ordinances or resolutions previously enacted by City Council or new
matter ordained by the Adopting Ordinance. Sections and subsections of the 1973
Codified Ordinances without a history or with the words “Adopting Ordinance” at
the end thereof are or contain new matter ordained by the Adopting Ordinance.
In the following table, the disposition of all source material in the 1973
Kenton Codified Ordinances is indicated.

TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
EXPLANATION OF TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
   The Codified Ordinances of Wapakoneta comprises all ordinances and
resolutions of a general and permanent nature. The provisions of such general
and permanent ordinances and resolutions are set forth in full in the Codified
Ordinances.
   References must be made frequently to many special ordinances and
resolutions, particularly those relating to property, such as easements,
vacations, dedications, acquisitions and disposals, leases, etc. In the
following Tables A through I, all such ordinances and resolutions are listed.
These Tables list ordinances and resolutions chronologically by subject and
include both a citation to and a brief description of each ordinance and
resolution.
TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
         
TABLE A   -   Franchises
         
TABLE B   -   Easements
         
TABLE C   -   Vacating of Streets and Alleys
         
TABLE D   -   Dedication and Plat Approval
         
TABLE E   -   Acquisition and Disposal of Real Property
            
TABLE F   -   Lease of Real Property
         
TABLE G   -   Grade Levels and Change of Street Name
         
TABLE H   -   Annexation and Detachment of Territory
         
TABLE I   -   Zoning Map Changes

Codified Ordinances

606.06 
202.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   This volume consists of all ordinances and resolutions of a permanent and
general nature of the Municipality, as revised and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections, and as such shall be known and designated
as the Codified Ordinances of Kenton, Ohio, 1973, for which designation
“Codified Ordinances” may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section
headings do not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified
Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
202.02 GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless otherwise expressly provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)   “And” may be read “or”, and “or” may be read “and”, if the sense
requires it.
   (b)   “Another,” when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
   (c)   “Bond” includes an undertaking.
   (d)   “Child” includes child by adoption.
   (e)   “Council” means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (f)   “County” means Hardin County, Ohio.
   (g)   “Fire Chief” shall include the Chief of the Fire Department if such
Fire Department has been established in the Municipality, and shall include the
Fire Prevention Officer if no Fire Department has been established in the
Municipality.
   (h)   “Imprisoned” shall have the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 1.05.
   (i)   “Internet” means the international computer network of both federal
and non-federal interoperable packet switched data networks, including the
graphical subnetwork known as the world wide web.
   (j)   “Keeper” or “proprietor” includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent, or employee.
   (k)   “Land” or “real estate” includes rights and easements of incorporeal
nature.
   (l)   “Legislative authority” means the legislative authority of the
Municipality.
   (m)   “May” is permissive.
   (n)   “Municipality” or “Village,” when used in this Model Ohio Municipal
Code, shall denote the Municipality irrespective of its population or legal
classification.
   (o)   “OAC” refers to the Ohio Administrative Code.
   (p)   “Oath” includes affirmation; and “swear” includes affirm.
   (q)   “Of unsound mind” The person lacks the relevant mental capacity.
   (r)   “Ohio R.C.,” “ORC” or “Revised Code” refers to the Ohio Revised Code.
   (s)   “Owner,” when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner, or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (t)   “Person” includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership, and association.
   (u)   “Personal property” includes all property except real property.
   (v)   “Plan of sewerage,” “system of sewerage,” “sewer,” and “sewers”
includes sewers, sewage disposal works and treatment plants, and sewage pumping
stations, together with facilities and appurtenances necessary and proper
therefor.
   (w)   “Premises,” as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (x)   “Property” includes real, personal, mixed estates, and interests.
   (y)   “Public authority” includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State, or Federal government, its officers, or an agency thereof; or
any duly authorized public official.
   (z)   “Public place” includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation, or amusement.
   (aa)   “Real property” includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments.
   (bb)   “Registered mail” includes certified mail; and “certified mail”
includes registered mail.
   (cc)   “Shall” is mandatory.
   (dd)   “Sidewalk” means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (ee)   “State” means the State of Ohio.
   (ff)   “Street” includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads,
highways, viaducts, and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (gg)   “Tenant” or “occupant,” as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (hh)   “Undertaking” includes a bond.
   (ii)   “Week” means seven consecutive days.
   (jj)   “Whoever”includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents, and employees; and all officials, public or private.
   (kk)   “Writing” includes printing.
   (ll)   “Written” or in “writing” include any representation of words,
letters, symbols, or figures; this provision does not affect any law relating
to signatures.
   (mm)   “Year” means twelve consecutive months.
(ORC 1.02, 1.05, 1.44, 1.59, 701.01)
202.03 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Use. Words and phrases shall be read in context
and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words and
phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in these Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)   Words in the present tense include the future tense.
(ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Computation of Time.
      (1)   The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day; except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal holiday.
      (2)   When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be
performed, is closed to the public for the entire day that constitutes the last
day for doing the act or before its usual closing time on that day, the act may
be performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal
holiday.
      (3)   “Legal holiday,” as used in divisions (c)(1) and (c)(2) of this
section, means the following days:
         A.   The first day of January, known as New Year’s day;
         B.   The third Monday in January, known as Martin Luther King day;
         C.   The third Monday in February, known as Washington-Lincoln day;
         D.   The day designated in the “Act of June 28, 1968,” 82 Stat. 250, 5
U.S.C. 6103, as amended, for the commemoration of Memorial day;
         E.   The nineteenth day of June, known as Juneteenth day;
         F.   The fourth day of July, known as Independence day;
         G.   The first Monday in September, known as Labor day;
         H.   The second Monday in October, known as Columbus Day;
         I.   The eleventh day of November, known as Veteran’s day;
         J.   The fourth Thursday in November, known as Thanksgiving day;
         K.   The twenty-fifth day of December, known as Christmas day;
         L.   Any day appointed and recommended by the Governor of this State
or the President of the United States as a holiday.
      (4)   If any day designated in this section as a legal holiday falls on a
Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
(ORC 1.14)
      (5)   When an act is to take effect or become operative from and after a
day named, no part of that day shall be included. If priority of legal rights
depends upon the order of events on the same day, such priority shall be
determined by the times in the day at which they respectively occurred.
(ORC 1.15)
      (6)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from
a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which. the computation is begun, unless
there are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period
ends on the last day of that month.
(ORC 1.45) (Ord. 21-036. Passed 12-27-21.)
202.04 REVIVOR; EFFECT OF RE-ENACTMENT, AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing provision of the Codified Ordinances does
not revive the provision originally repealed nor impair the effect of any
saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   The re-enactment, amendment, or repeal of the Codified Ordinances does
not, except as provided in division (c) of this section:
      (1)   Affect the prior operation of the provision or any prior action
taken thereunder.
      (2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation, or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded, or incurred thereunder.
      (3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture, or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal.
      (4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding, or remedy in respect of any
privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture, or punishment; and the
investigation, proceeding, or remedy may be instituted, continued, or enforced,
and the penalty, forfeiture, or punishment imposed, as if the provision had not
been repealed or amended.
   (c)   If the penalty, forfeiture, or punishment for any offense is reduced
by a re-enactment or amendment of a provision of the Codified Ordinances, the
penalty, forfeiture, or punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed
according to the provision of the Codified Ordinances as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
202.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
section or an inclusive group of sections, or of divisions or subdivisions of a
section, such reference shall be construed to mean a violation of any provision
of the section, sections, divisions or subdivisions included in the reference.
   (b)   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized
under designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case,
action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
   (c)   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof,
the reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered, unless the subject matter be
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
(ORC 1.55)
202.06 SEPARABILITY.
   If any provisions of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
202.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates or fails to comply with any such provision
is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined no more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 204
Official Standards
   Editor's note: The State of Ohio operates on Eastern Daylight Savings Time
from 2:00 a.m. of the first Sunday in April until 2:00 a.m. of the last Sunday
in October. Congress, on March 22, 1966, passed the Uniform Time Act requiring
uniform observance throughout the nation of Daylight Savings Time starting in
1967, except that a State legislature could exempt the entire state from
Daylight Savings Time or divide a state into not more than two parts, each with
a different time standard. The Ohio legislature, through inaction, has elected
to observe Eastern Daylight Savings Time throughout the State of Ohio.
On August 8, 2005, the Energy Policy Act of 2005 was enacted. This Act changed
the time change dates for Daylight Saving Time in the United States. Beginning
in 2007, the State of Ohio begins Daylight Saving Time at 2:00 a.m. on the
second Sunday in March and reverts to standard time at 2:00 a.m. on the first
Sunday in November. The Secretary of Energy will report the impact of this
change to Congress. Congress retains the right to resume the 2005 Daylight
Saving Time schedule once the Department of Energy study is complete.
   There are no sections in Chapter 204. This chapter has been established to
provide a place for cross references and any future legislation.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   State standard of time - see Ohio R.C. 1.04
   State legal holidays - see Ohio R.C. 1.14, 5.20 et seq., 1303.45
   State flag and other insignia - see Ohio R.C. 5.01 et seq.
   State seals - see Ohio R.C. 5.10 et seq.
   Sealer of Weights and Measures - see ADM.

Ch. 1234
206.01 FIRST WARD.
   The City is hereby divided into four wards. The boundaries of such wards
shall be as described in this section and Sections
206.02,
206.03 and
206.04.
   The First Ward shall consist of the following territory: commencing at the
center of the intersection of Main Street and Columbus Street in the City;
thence south with the center of Main Street to the south corporation line; then
in a northeasterly direction with the corporation line, to the east line of
such corporation; thence northerly, following the east line of such corporation
to the center of Columbus Street; thence west with the center of Columbus
Street to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1845. Passed 1-24-72.)
206.02 SECOND WARD.
   The Second Ward shall consist of the following territory: commencing at the
center of the intersection of Main Street and Columbus Street in the City;
thence easterly with the center of Columbus Street to the east line of the
corporation; thence northerly, following the east line of the corporation to
the north line thereof; thence westerly, following the north line of the
corporation to the center of Main Street; thence southerly with the center of
Main Street to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1845. Passed 1-24-72.)
206.03 THIRD WARD.
   The Third Ward shall consist of the following territory: commencing at the
center of the intersection of Main Street and Columbus Street in the City;
thence northerly with the center of Main Street to the north line of the
corporation; thence westerly, following the north line of the corporation to
the west line of the corporation; thence southerly, following the west line of
the corporation to the center of Lima Street; thence east with the center of
Lima Street to where the same intersects Columbus Street; thence east with the
center of Columbus Street to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1845. Passed 1-24-72.)
206.04 FOURTH WARD.
   The Fourth Ward shall consist of the following territory: commencing at the
center of the intersection of Main Street and Columbus Street in the City;
thence west with the center of Columbus Street to where the same intersects
Lima Street; thence west with the center of Lima Street to the west line of the
corporation; thence southerly, following the west line of the corporation to
the southwest corner thereof; thence in a general southeasterly direction,
following the south corporation line to the center of Main Street; thence
northerly with the center of Main Street to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 1845. Passed 1-24-72.)

208.01 PURCHASING OF FUEL FOR MUNICIPAL VEHICLES.
   The City shall assign a number to each of its vehicles, and all departments
and employees who purchase fuel for City vehicles from an approved vendor shall
cause such vehicle number to be entered upon the purchase record. The Auditor
shall maintain a list of such numbered vehicles and shall review fuel purchase
records to determine if all purchases are authorized and valid.
(Res. 92-018. Passed 11-9-92.)
208.02 COOPERATIVE PURCHASING.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety or the Director of Public Service is
hereby authorized, in the name of the City, to participate in State contracts
which the Department of Administrative Services, Office of State Purchasing,
has entered into for the purchase of supplies, services, equipment and certain
materials pursuant to Ohio R.C. 125.04.
   (b)   The Director of Public Safety or the Director of Public Service is
hereby authorized to agree, in the name of the City, to be bound by all
contract terms and conditions as the Department of Administrative Services,
Office of State Purchasing, prescribes. Such terms and conditions may include a
reasonable fee to cover the administrative costs which the Department of
Administrative Services, Office of State Purchasing, incurs as a result of the
City’s participation in a contract.
   (c)   The Director of Public Safety or the Director of Public Service is
hereby authorized to agree, in the name of the City, to directly pay the
vendor, under each such State contract in which the City participates, for
items it receives pursuant to such contract.
(Res. 92-015. Passed 10-12-92.)

222.01 ASSISTANT LAW DIRECTOR.
   The position of Assistant Law Director is hereby created. The Law Director
of the City may hire an individual to fill the position of Assistant Law
Director, and such position shall carry such duties and responsibilities as may
be determined by the Law Director. The compensation to be received by the
Assistant Law Director shall be such as may be determined by Council from time
to time, and bond shall be provided according to Section 246.02(a).
(Ord. 1938. Passed 2-25-74.)
222.02 CITY PROSECUTOR.
   There is hereby established the position of City Prosecutor, which shall be
filled by appointment of the Director of Law. The City Prosecutor and his or
her duly appointed assistants shall be Assistant Directors of Law. The duties
of the City Prosecutor shall be those prescribed from time to time by the
Director of Law or Council.

Deputy Auditor at a compensation to be determined from time to time by Council.

with Ohio R.C. 731.57.

230.02   ISSUANCE OF CITATIONS FOR PARKING METER VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   The Public Safety Director is hereby authorized to hire not more than
four persons for the purpose of writing and issuing citations for parking meter
violations within the City.
   (b)   The powers and duties of such persons shall be limited to the writing
and issuing of citations upon forms authorized by the Director or the
ordinances of the City relating to metered parking within the City for the
illegal parking of vehicles in metered parking spaces within the City.
   (c)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the powers of the
Police Department to write and issue such citations in the course of their
regular duties.
   (d)   Such persons shall be under the supervision of the Director who shall
formulate rules and regulations concerning the schedule of employment, hours of
work and rates of pay for each person employed pursuant to this section.
(Ord. 1876. Passed 10-24-72.)
230.03 SPECIAL DUTY POLICEMEN AND FIREMEN.
   (a)   The Public Safety Director is hereby authorized to hire policemen and
firemen for emergency special duty assignments as he or she may deem necessary.
   (b)   The policemen and firemen who are so hired shall be compensated on an
hourly rate which shall be computed by dividing their respective annual
salaries by the total number of hours worked annually based upon a 48-hour
week.
   (c)   Such policemen and firemen so hired shall be paid out of the Police or
Fire Salary Appropriation of the General Fund.
(Ord. 1483. Passed 8-8-66.)
230.04 PART-TIME CLERK.
   The Public Safety and Public Service Directors are hereby authorized and
directed to employ a competent part-time clerk to assist the several City
departments.
(Ord. 1472. Passed 6-2-66.)
230.05 SOURCE OF SAFETY SERVICE DIRECTOR’S SALARY.
   The salary of the Safety Service Director shall be paid from the following
funds in the proportion indicated:
   (a)   General Fund: 40%.
   (b)   Street Fund: 10%.
   (c)   Water Fund: 25%.
   (d)   Sewer Fund: 25%.
(Ord. 92-002. Passed 1-13-92; Ord. 06-044. Passed 12-11-06; Ord. 21-036. Passed
12-27-21.)
CHAPTER 232
Police Department
   EDITOR’S NOTE: The City contracts with the Fraternal Order of Police, Ohio

and conditions of employment for eligible employees in the Police Department.

232.01 COMPOSITION.
   The Police Department shall be composed of a Chief of Police, one
Lieutenant, two Sergeants and regular certified patrolmen and probationary
appointees in such number as Council shall from time to time determine. The
members of the Department shall be compensated as provided by Council and shall
be paid biweekly from the Police Fund of the General Fund.
232.02 PROMOTIONS.
   Eligibility required for the ranks of Chief, Lieutenant and Sergeants shall
be as follows: five years service as a Patrolman after the probationary period
for Chief of Police; three years service as a Patrolman after the probationary
period for Lieutenant of Police; one year service as a Patrolman after the
probationary period for Sergeant. Promotion shall be by successive ranks so far
as practicable. No person in the Department shall be promoted to a position in
a higher rank who has not served at least twelve months in the next lower rank.
(Ord. 1224. Passed 10-16-61.)
232.03 AGE LIMITS FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   A person between the ages of twenty-one and thirty-six inclusive may receive
an original appointment to the Police Department.
(Ord. 1840. Passed 10-28-71.)
232.04 PRIVATE POLICE.
   (a)   The Safety-Service Director, whenever he sees fit, on the application
of any person who shows the necessity therefor, may commission one or more
private policemen under Ohio R.C. 737.05, for duty at any place in the City.
Such private policemen shall not be in the classified service of the City and
shall derive their compensation from private sources.
   (b)   Each private policeman, after being sworn, shall be subject to the
orders of the Director and shall be governed by such rules and regulations as
the Director may prescribe. He shall wear a badge furnished to him by the
Director, provided he first deposits five dollars ($5.00) with the Clerk of
Council to be held as security for the return of the badge when the special
privilege granted is surrendered or recalled.
   (c)   Each private policeman shall be subject to suspension or dismissal for
conduct while on duty which, in the opinion of the Director, requires such
action.
(Ord. 1560. Passed 10-9-67.)
232.05 POLICE DISPATCHER.
   The position of police dispatcher is hereby created and three such
dispatchers are authorized to be hired, by the Safety-Service Director and as
provided in ordinances concerning wages and salaries as from time to time
adopted by Council. Such persons hired as dispatchers shall be under the
administrative supervision of the Chief of Police and shall work within the
Police Department but shall have no authority as police officers. Such persons
shall be considered employees of the City and entitled to all benefits of such
employees and shall give bond in accordance with Chapter 246.
(Ord. 2087. Passed 3-28-77.)
232.06 AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE.
   (a)   Appointment of Members. There is hereby created an Auxiliary Police
Force, the members of which shall be appointed by the Safety-Service Director
upon the nomination of the Chief of Police.
   (b)   Term of Service. Auxiliary police officers shall serve so long as the
Director may direct, or until a resignation submitted by such member is
accepted by the Director.
   (c)   Qualifications of Members. Members of the Auxiliary Police Force shall
not be under the age of twenty-one years at the time of their appointment. No
residency requirement shall apply.
(Ord. 05-007. Passed 4-25-04.)
   (d)   Control. The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the
Auxiliary Police Force and, subject to the approval of the Director, shall have
control of the assignment, training, stationing and direction of work of such
Force. The Auxiliary Police Force will have all police powers, but shall
perform only such police duties as are assigned by the Chief of Police and
shall act only when in the prescribed uniform or portion of a uniform. The
Chief of Police shall prescribe the time and place such uniform or portion
thereof shall be worn. Such auxiliary members shall obey the chain of command
of the Police Department and shall take orders from all regularly appointed
members thereof.
(Ord. 79-034. Passed 7-30-79.)
   (e)   Rules and Regulations. The Chief of Police shall, with the approval of
the Director, prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct, control and
compensation of the Auxiliary Police Force.
   (f)   Services Within the City. Services performed by Auxiliary police
officers shall only be performed when the officer is on duty and then only
within the City, except when accompanying a regular police officer outside the
City.
(Ord. 88-007. Passed 4-25-88.)
   (g)   Nonclassified Service; Workers’ Compensation. Auxiliary police
officers shall not be deemed to be in the classified service of the City but
shall, nonetheless, be considered employees of the City when performing duties
pursuant to the laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the City pertaining
to such police officers. Such police officers shall be covered by workers’
compensation in accordance with Industrial Commission rules and regulations
pertaining to volunteer police officers and fire officers as public employees.
   (h)   Bond and Uniform. Each member of the Auxiliary Police Force, as a
condition precedent to serving thereon, shall furnish, at City expense, a bond
in the amount and upon the same terms and conditions as is required of a
regular appointed policeman. Each member of the Auxiliary Police Force shall be
provided with the prescribed uniform at the expense of the City.
   (i)   Liability Insurance. The City shall furnish and pay for liability
insurance coverage for all active reserve police officers while performing
duties under this section.
   (j)   Nonliability. This section is hereby declared to be an exercise by the
City of its police powers for the protection of the public peace, health,
property, safety and general welfare, and neither the City, nor an agent or
representative of the City, nor any individual, firm, partnership or
corporation, or the receiver or trustee or any other agent thereof, who in good
faith executes any executive order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to
this section, shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to any person or
property as a direct or proximate result of such action.
   (k)   Executive Orders. The Safety-Service Director is hereby authorized and
directed to promulgate such executive orders, rules and regulations as, at his
or her discretion, are deemed to be either necessary or desirable in the
administration of the Auxiliary Police Force.
   (l)   Interpretation. The provisions of this section, individually or
severally, shall not be construed as intended by Council to be in conflict with
any Federal or State statute or with any military or naval order, rule or
regulation.
(Ord. 79-034. Passed 7-30-79.)
232.07   LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   There is hereby established a Law Enforcement Trust Fund to receive proceeds
from the sale of contraband pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2933.43 and mandatory fines
and forfeited bail pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2925.03, for the uses and purposes
described and subject to the limitations contained therein.
(Res. 89-015. Passed 8-28-89.)

234.01 COMPOSITION.
   The Fire Department shall be composed of the following officers and other
members, who shall receive salaries as provided in ordinances concerning wages
and salaries as from time to time adopted by Council, payable biweekly out of
the Fire Fund of the General Fund of the City:
   (a)   A Chief;
   (b)   An Assistant Captain (optional);
   (c)   Three Captains;
   (d)   Not more than sixteen regular certified firefighters.
(Ord. 2085. Passed 2-28-77; Ord. 21-036. Passed 12-27-21.)
234.02 PROMOTIONS.
   Eligibility required for the ranks of Chief, Assistant Chief and Captain
shall be as follows: five years service as a Fireman after the probationary
period for Fire Chief; three years service as a Fireman after the probationary
period for Assistant Fire Chief; one year service as a Fireman after the
probationary period for Captain. Promotion shall be by successive ranks so far
as practicable. No person in the Department shall be promoted to a position in
a higher rank who has not served at least twelve months in the next lower rank.
(Ord. 1225. Passed 10-16-61.)
234.03 AGE LIMITS FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   A person between the ages of eighteen and thirty-six inclusive may receive
an original appointment to the Fire Department.
234.04 NONRESIDENT SERVICE.
   (a)   The Fire Department is hereby authorized to extend its services and
use of its fire apparatus and equipment to any political subdivision within
Hardin County, in times of emergency.
   (b)   The Safety-Service Director and Fire Chief, on behalf of the Fire
Department, are hereby authorized to join and participate in the efforts of the
Hardin County Fire Fighters Association to effect a workable plan which would
provide protection against common disasters occurring within Hardin County.
(Ord. 1551. Passed 6-26-67.)
234.05 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   All members/employees of the Fire Department, including any person receiving
an original and permanent appointment as a fire-fighter in the Fire Department,
shall be required, as a condition of employment, to reside in Hardin County, in
any county adjacent to Hardin County, or in any of the following counties in
Ohio: Putnam, Shelby, Champaign, Delaware, Morrow, Crawford, or Seneca.
(Ord. 2153. Passed 5-22-78; Ord. 17-032. Passed 9-11-17; Ord. 21-036. Passed
12-27-21.)
234.06 PAYMENT OF FIRE LOSS CLAIMS.
   (a)   The City hereby adopts and accepts the provisions and procedures set
forth in Ohio R.C. 3929.86, particularly subsections (C) and (D) thereof,
providing for the transfer and receipt of portions of fire insurance proceeds
as set forth in said section.
   (b)   The Safety-Service Director is hereby designated as the officer of the
City to carry out the duties under Ohio R.C. 3929.86.
(Ord. 89-036-A. Passed 9-25-89.)

238.01 CREATION; SUPERINTENDENT OF THE DEPARTMENT.
   There is hereby created a Department of Water and Sanitary Sewage, together
with the position of Superintendent thereof, who shall manage, operate and be
in charge of the Department and be responsible for the conduct thereof. The
Safety-Service Director shall be ex-officio Superintendent of the Department.
(Ord. 1084. Passed 1-25-55.)
238.02 AUTHORITY OF DEPARTMENT.
   The operation and maintenance of the Department of Water and Sanitary Sewage
in its entirety within the City and the operation and maintenance of the
sewerage system, together with the collection of water and sewer rental charges
and the supervision of the water and sewerage systems, shall be done and
performed by the Department of Water and Sanitary Sewage. (Ord. 1084. Passed 1-
25-55.)
238.03 ADMINISTRATION CODE
   The Safety-Service Director, as Superintendent of the Water and Sanitary
Sewage Department, shall transfer such employees as may be necessary for the
operation of the Department, or shall provide, by part-time service from
existing City employees, the necessary personnel for the creation and operation
of the Department. The City Auditor shall supervise and install proper books of
account for the Department, and such books of account shall be maintained by
the Department subject to audit as provided by law, by the City Auditor. The
superintendent of the Department shall prepare such rules and regulations
governing the manner in which the Department shall be conducted and its
services furnished to the inhabitants of the City, as he may determine to be
necessary, which shall be submitted to Council for approval before becoming
effective.
(Ord. 1084. Passed 1-25-55.)
238.04 SUPERINTENDENT OF THE SEWAGE DISPOSAL PLANT.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Superintendent of the
Kenton Sewage Disposal Plant in the Department of Water and Sanitary Sewage of
the City, which office shall be deemed to be one to be filled in compliance
with the civil service statutes of the State and under the classified service,
competitive class, as therein defined.
   (b)   This position shall be filled by appointment of the Safety-Service
Director who, under authority of Section
238.01, is the Superintendent of the Department of Water and Sanitary Sewage,
such appointment to be made from the eligible list as certified by the Civil
Service Commission.
   (c)   The Superintendent of the Kenton Sewage Disposal Plant shall manage,
control and supervise the operation of the Plant under the direction and
supervision of the Safety-Service Director.
(Ord. 1123. Passed 8-20-56.)

249.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known as the “General Classification and Salary
Ordinance,” for those personnel not covered by a collective bargaining
agreement.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section.
   (a)   “Active service” means being present for the performance of the duties
to which an officer or employee of the City has been assigned.
   (b)   “Allocation” means an action, reserved exclusively to civil service
commissions, having the effect of placing positions in classes established by a
commission.
   (c)   “Appointing authority” means an officer, board agency, commission or
person having the power to appoint and terminate workers according to law and
the rules and regulations established by the Civil Service Commission.
   (d)   “Appointment” means the designation of a person, by competent
authority, to be an employee in a position and his/her induction into such
position.
   (e)   “Calendar week” means seven consecutive days starting at 12:01 AM on
Saturday and ending at midnight the following Friday.
   (f)   “Class” means a position, or group of positions, having similar duties
and responsibilities, requiring similar qualification, which can be properly
identified by the same descriptive title and to which the same scale of
compensation can be made to apply with equity.
   (g)   “Classified service” means all positions and employment not
specifically included as being in the unclassified service.
   (h)   “Continuous service” means service not interrupted by resignation,
retirement or discharge.
   (i)   “Demotion” means a change of an employee from a position in one class
to a position in a different class having a lower maximum rate of pay.
   (j)   “Downgrading” means an action taken by Council reducing all the
position in a class to a lower pay range.
   (k)   “Full-time employment” means active service in a position of
employment performed for a minimum of thirty-five (35) hours of work per
calendar week for an indefinite period of time.
   (1)   “Immediate family” means mother, father, brother, sister, child,
spouse, grandchild, grandparent, mother-in-law, father-in-law, daughter-in-law,
son-in-law, legal guardian or other person who stands in place of a parent.
   (m)   “Original appointment” means initial appointment of a person to a
position in the Municipal service or appointment after service has been
interrupted by resignation, retirement or discharge.
   (n)   “Paid status” means time for which the employee is paid including
authorized leave with pay.
   (o)   “Part-time employment” means active service in any position for less
than thirty-five (35) hours per calendar week.
   (p)   “Pay plan” means a schedule of compensation rates established by
Council for the classes of positions contained in the official classification
plan maintained by the Civil Service Commission.
   (q)   “Permanent civil service status” means the rights acquired by an
employee occupying a position in the classified service who has been appointed
from an eligible list and has successfully completed a working-test period.
   (r)   “Position” means any specific employment or job consisting of duties
and responsibilities assigned by competent authority. A position may be full-
time, part-time, seasonal or temporary; it may be occupied or vacant.
   (s)   “Promotion” means a change from a position in one class to a position
in a different class having a higher maximum rate of pay.
   (t)   “Provisional appointment” means the appointment of a qualified person
to a position in the classified service in the absence of an eligible list.
   (u)   “Range” means the minimum and maximum pay rates, together with the
intermediate pay rates or steps, if any, established for a class.
   (v)   “Reallocation” means an action taken by a Civil Service Commission
that has the effect of changing the title and responsibilities of the job, or
to correct an error in the changes in the duties and responsibilities of the
job, or to correct an error in the previous classification of the job.
   (w)   “Re-employment” means an appointment of person from a re-employment
list, whose name has been placed on the list within one year of the date of his
or her resignation providing such person has not reached his or her sixty-fifth
birthday. Names place on a re-employment list shall be eligible for appointment
for a period of two years from the date the name was entered on such re-
employment list.
   (x)   “Reinstatement” means the return of an employee to his or her former
position following a layoff.
   (y)   “Seasonal employment” means full-time or part-time employment for a
specific part of a calendar year rather than for an indefinite period of time.
   (z)   “Step” or “increment” means each of the regular pay steps or
increments, in a pay range.
   (aa)   “Upgrading” means an action taken by Council to move a classification
from one salary range to a higher range.
   (bb)   “Weekend” means the first and second day of unscheduled work in an
employee’s workweek.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.03 EMPLOYEE STATUS.
   (a)   All employees of the City shall be classified as full-time, part-time,
temporary, seasonal, intermittent or interim, as follows:
      (1)   Full-time employee: An employee who is scheduled at least thirty-
five (35) hours per calendar week on a regular scheduled basis.
      (2)   Part-time employee: An employee who is scheduled less than thirty-
five (35) hours per calendar week, but on a regularly scheduled basis.
      (3)   Temporary employee: An employee hired for a limited period of time,
fixed by the appointing authority, for a period not to exceed ninety (90) work
days. A temporary employee normally is exempted from participating in the
Public Employees Retirement System (PERS).
      (4)   Seasonal employee: An employee who works a certain regular season
or period of the year performing some work or activity limited to that season
or period of the year. A seasonal employee is not exempted from participating
in PERS.
      (5)   Intermittent employee: An employee who works an irregular schedule,
which is determined by the fluctuating demands of the work, which are not
predicable. Intermittent employees work no longer than 1040 hours per calendar
year and are not exempted from participating in PERS.
      (6)   Interim employees: An employee hired to fill a vacancy created by
the sickness or disability of a regular employee for the period of the sickness
or disability. Interim employees are not exempted from participating in PERS.
   (b)   Full-time employees shall be entitled to all benefits provided to the
City. Part-time police dispatchers are entitled to vacation and sick leave
only. All other part-time employees are entitled to sick leave only. Temporary,
seasonal, intermittent and interim employees are not eligible for sick leave,
holiday pay, vacation or insurance benefits.
   (c)   If a part-time, permanent, temporary, seasonal, intermittent or
interim employee works thirty-five (35) hours or more per week, for more than
thirty (30) days, he or she may apply for a change of status. The decision to
grant the change of status shall be left to the discretion of the appointing
authority.
   (d)   Employees may change their status only with the approval of the
appointing authority and when it is in the best interest of the department.
   (e)   Interim appointees are to be notified, in writing, as a condition of
employment, that their appointment shall cease upon the return of the regular
employee for whom the interim employee is working. Likewise, temporary and
seasonal employees shall be so notified that their employment is of a temporary
or seasonal nature. Such notification shall also include the date of hire and
anticipated date of cessation of employment.
   (f)   The following classifications shall be designated as department heads/
management: Fire Chief, Police Chief, Chief Deputy Auditor, Public Works
Superintendent, Municipal Court Clerk, Safety and Service Director, Income Tax
Administrator, Wastewater Treatment Plant Superintendent Operator of Record,
Water Treatment Plant Superintendent Operator of Record, and Parks and
Recreation Director. The Safety and Service Director and Income Tax
Administrator shall be appointed by the Mayor. The Fire Chief, Police Chief,
Public Works Superintendent, Wastewater Treatment Plant Superintendent Operator
of Record, Water Treatment Plant Superintendent Operator of Record, Parks and
Recreation Director and other service employees shall be appointed by the
Safety and Service Director. The Auditor shall appoint the Chief Deputy Auditor
and other audit employees. The Municipal Court Judge shall appoint the
Municipal Court Clerk. The Municipal Court Clerk shall appoint Deputy Court
Clerks. Council shall appoint the Clerk of Council.
   (g)   The following employees are designated as confidential, supervisory,
fiduciary, management and/or otherwise exempted personnel below the department
head level. Class title: Chief Deputy Court Clerk, Customer Service Supervisor,
Deputy Court Clerk, Police Lieutenant, Police Sergeant, Assistant Fire Chief,
Fire Captain, and Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02; Ord. 16-028. Passed 7-25-16; Ord. 17-014. Passed
5-22-17.)
249.04 MANAGEMENT, ORGANIZATION AND PERSONNEL COMMITTEE.
   The President of Council shall biennially appoint a Management, Organization
and Personnel committee from the members of Council to assist in the
administration of this chapter, to study personnel matters and make
recommendations as to necessary legislation thereto and to perform other duties
and responsibilities as designated by the President of Council.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.05 PREPARATION AND CONTENT OF POSITION SPECIFICATIONS.
   Position specifications shall be prepared by the Safety/Service Director and
are maintained by him or her following their adoption by the Civil Service
Commission for classified positions or by the appointing authority for
unclassified positions and specify the desirable qualifications for successful
performance of such duties.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.06 ADOPTION OF CLASSIFICATION PLAN.
   The classification plan shall consist of the classification titles and pay
assignments and position specification, as adopted by the Civil Service
Commission in the case of classified positions, or the appointment authority in
the case of un-classified positions. This plan shall be on file in the office
of the Safety/Service Director and the Clerk of Council. The Safety/Service
Director and the Management, Organization and Personnel Committee shall, from
time to time, make necessary recommendations for changes in the plant to the
Civil Service Commission to reflect current duties, responsibilities and
qualification, and upon their adoption shall report to Council periodically of
these changes. As used in this chapter, “employee” means, unless otherwise
specified, all management level, supervisory, confidential, administrative or
other personnel not covered by collective bargaining agreements.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.07 PURPOSE AND EFFECT OF CLASS SPECIFICATIONS.
   Each class specification shall outline the main characteristics and
qualification requirements of positions in the class and shall give examples of
specific duties to be performed. These specifications shall be descriptive and
explanatory but not restrictive. The examples listed shall not preclude the
assignment of other tasks and duties of related kind or character.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.08 APPLICATION OF SPECIFICATION TO POSITIONS.
   In determining the class to which a new position should be allocated the
specifications of such class shall be considered in it entirety and in relation
to the specifications of other classes in the classification plan.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.09 STATEMENT OF REQUIREMENT QUALIFICATION.
   The statement of qualification requirements in class specification is
intended to be used as a guide in selecting candidates for employment, as an
aid in preparing competitive examination, and for use in determining the
relative value of positions in one class with positions on other classes.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.10 PROHIBITED DISCRIMINATIONS.
   The establishment and application of class specification pay ranges, and
other related actions shall be made without regard to race, religion, sex,
color, creed, or national origin except that all employees must be citizens of
the United States of America.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.11 COMPENSATION SCHEDULES.
   The pay of Municipal employees shall be on the basis of the appropriate
ranges of the salary (S) or hourly (H) rates as prescribed for the respective
job titles and pay ranges.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
249.12 TITLES USED AND PAY RANGES APPLIED TO CLASSES.
   The meanings of the position titles used herein shall be defined by
specifications contained in the classification plan. For each class of position
there is hereby established the pay range shown opposite each title in Section
249.13. Such section to be known as the classification titles and pay
assignments portion of any interested person during the regular business hours.
Positions will be designated as paid on an hourly or a salary basis.
(Ord. 02-013. Passed 8-26-02.)
